tooltips.region: Geographic areas where climate change/sea level rise vulnerability studies have been conducted.
tooltips.climate: Future planning horizons representing the impact of climate change.
tooltips.scenario: Sea level rise scenarios (low, medium, and high) based on the regional sea level rise amounts.
tooltips.hurricane: Hurrican categories (Saffir-Simpson hurricane wind scale, ranging from 1 to 5) used to model storm surge heights.
tooltips.dataSource: Source of hazard data to be mapped in the application.
tooltips.sealevelrise: Sea level rise inundation scenarios ranging from zero to six feet above mean higher high water (MHHW).

tooltips.scenario: Sea level rise scenarios (intermediate low, intermediate, high, and extreme) based on regional sea level rise amounts estimated using the same methodology used for NOAA’s Sea Level Rise and Coastal Flooding Impacts viewer.
tooltips.stormSurge:
Modeled storms based on stakeholder-identified areas of interest, including

Low Intensity: three Category 1 hurricanes with maximum winds of 80 mph;
Medium Intensity: six Category 1 and 2 hurricanes with maximum winds between 85 and 110 mph;
High Intensity: seven Category 2 and 3 hurricanes with maximum winds between 95 and 115 mph;
Nor’Ida: surge generated by that particular storm only, which occurred in 2009.

Note that these storms do not have a probability of occurrence associated with them. Displayed on the map is the maximum storm surge water depth for multiple modeled storms in each intensity category.
tooltips.radiogroup_storm_surge: Storm surge modeled for multiple storm and sea-level rise scenarios displayed as the potential maximum storm surge water depth or estimated total economic losses by census block (developed using the FEMA HAZUS-MH risk analysis software). These data should only be used for planning purposes.
tooltips.togglegroup_surgedepth: Current scenario year only applies to storm surge water depth while future scenario years can also be displayed as the difference between the selected year and current conditions (absolute or percent difference). This is important because a given sea level rise will not affect all places equally.
tooltips.storm_track_na: Show storm tracks for the group of storms representing each storm type used in the modeling.
tooltips.storm_tide_na: Show tidal range at various locations to assess the potential variability in water depth for a given storm type.  While storm surge modeling was based on mean tide level, water depth will vary depending on the tide at which the maximum surge occurs.

options.name: Basic Inundation
options.description: Historical sea level trends are available from NOAA tide stations at Wachapreague and Kiptopeke.
options.footer: Note: basic inundation data have been updated based on sea level rise scenarios from the 2017 National Climate Assessment.
